Fig. 8 Template-free synthesis of novel TiO2 microtube (MT) and N-doped MT and their photocatalytic properties decomposing organic compounds Young In Jeon Investigation Methodology Data curation a You Jin Park Methodology Formal analysis a Jia Hong Pan Conceptualization Data curation b ⁎ Wan In Lee Conceptualization Supervision a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inha University, Incheon 22212, South Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inha University Incheon 22212 South Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inha University, Incheon 22212, Korea b MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, China MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 China MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Novel TiO2 microtubes (MTs) with a pore size of ∼1.6 µm, a wall thickness of ∼200 nm, and lengths of 15–30 µm were synthesized by solvothermal reaction without templates. TiO2 MTs, self-assembled with highly crystallized anatase particles, were obtained at the specific concentration ranges of titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP) and tetrabutyl ammonium hydroxide (TBAH) (0.32–0.45 M TTIP and 0.32–0.38 M TBAH). We also prepared nitrogen-doped TiO2 (N-TiO2) MTs by flowing gaseous ammonia to the bare TiO2 MTs at 550 °C and analyzed the photocatalytic properties of TiO2 MT and N-TiO2 MT in decomposing gaseous isopropanol (IPA) and aqueous salicylic acid (SA). Under UV–visible light illumination TiO2 MT showed slightly lower photocatalytic activities than commercial TiO2 NP (Aeroxide P25), but under visible light N-TiO2 MT demonstrated 2.2–3.4 times higher activities than N-TiO2 NP, presumably due to its effective structure for space-charge separation of the photogenerated electron/hole pairs. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords TiO2 Nanotube Microtube Solvothermal reaction Visible light photocatalyst Nitrogen doping Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is a wide band gap semiconductor that attracts extensive attention and is investigated in depth for various applications, owing to its outstanding electrical, optical, and physicochemical properties [1–4]. Tailoring of the TiO2 nanostructures with large surface area, high crystallinity, controlled morphology, and porosity can be key challenges for their diverse applications to the solar cells [5–8], photocatalysts [9,10], sensors [11,12], electrochromic devices [13,14], rechargeable batteries [15,16], micro-machines [17], and others. TiO2 nanostructures with tubular morphology are considered one of the promising architectures for the above-mentioned applications due to their straight pore channel and robust wall structure eligible for the efficient transport of mass and charge. To date, TiO2 nanotubes (NTs) with pore diameters smaller than a few hundred nanometers or TiO2 microtubes (MTs) with micrometer-dimension pores have been investigated diversely. Conventionally, TiO2 NTs have been fabricated using either inorganic templates such as anodized alumina [18–25] and mesoporous silica [26,27] or organic templates [28–30]. Typically, titania layers are deposited on the template surfaces by electrochemical deposition [19], sol-gel process [23–30], or vapor deposition technique such as atomic layer deposition [20–22], followed by thermal treatment and elimination of templates to obtain tubular TiO2 nanostructures. Noticeably, as template-free synthetic methods, hydrothermal reactions [31–34] and anodic oxidation of Ti foil [35–37] have been developed. For instance, Kasuga et al. reported the template-free preparation of TiO2 nanotubes (NTs) by hydrothermal reaction [31,32]. Typically, TiO2 NT with ∼8 nm outer diameter and 1–2 nm wall thickness was prepared by using TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) as the Ti source in a highly concentrated NaOH solution. Although it is a significant achievement in diversifying titania nanostructures, the obtained TiO2 NT only offers limited applications due to their too small pore size and poor material stability [34]. In contrast, the robust TiO2 NT arrays with diameters around 100 nm have been prepared successfully by anodic oxidation of Ti foil [35,36]. However, the synthetic process is not economically viable, and mass production of TiO2 NT structures is not available. Meanwhile, MT structures have received relatively less attention, and their synthetic method has not been investigated systematically. To form the TiO2 MT structures, in most cases, sol-gel process was applied to the various templates such as glass, [37] carbon [38], carbon nitride [39], and organic fibers [40,41]. As template-free methods, the electrospinning-based sol-gel process [42,43] and the rolled-up method using pre-made TiO2 films [44,45] were developed. Additionally, there are a few synthetic examples employing solvothermal reaction with including organic materials and Ti-precursors, but the shapes of the prepared tubular structures were not properly controlled [46,47]. In the present work, we prepared the unique TiO2 microtubes (MTs) with high uniformity by solvothermal reaction of titanium alkoxide in a bulky alkyl ammonium hydroxide without employing any template. Previously, we reported that TiO2 NPs, which form highly stable suspensions in an aqueous solution, could be prepared in very low concentrations of the tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAH) at ∼0.01 M, whereas TiO2 hollow microspheres (HMSs) could be obtained at more than 10 times higher concentrations of TBAH, i.e., over 0.1 M [48]. Unexpectedly, with further increasing the concentrations of TBAH, novel TiO2 MT structures, exhibiting excellent uniformity in tube diameter and wall thickness, were successfully synthesized. The prepared TiO2 MTs show a tubular structure possessing an outer diameter of ∼2 µm, a pore size of ∼1.6 µm, and lengths of 15–30 µm. For the selective preparation of the TiO2 MT phase, the concentrations of titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP) and TBAH during the solvothermal reaction turned out to be critical. The TiO2 HMS phase was formed at a relatively broad concentration range of TTIP and TBAH, but the formation of the TiO2 MT phase took place at significantly higher concentrations and a very narrow range of reactant compositions. We also investigated the formation mechanism of TiO2 MT structures by analyzing the intermediates during the solvothermal reaction. The prepared TiO2 MTs, composed of highly crystallized NPs that are tightly interconnected to form the wall structures, are considered to be effective for charge transport and space-charge separation for the photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Moreover, their wide and straight pore channels are suitable for fast transport of reactant and product molecules. Thus, it will be of great value to investigate photocatalytic property of TiO2 MTs. Herein, we prepared the nitrogen-doped TiO2 (N-TiO2) MTs from the as-prepared TiO2 MTs and then analyzed the photocatalytic properties of bare TiO2 MT and N-TiO2 MT under UV–visible light and visible light, respectively. From the results obtained, we elucidated the characteristics of TiO2 MT-based structures for application to photocatalytic reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Syntheses of TiO2 MTs and other TiO2 structures TiO2 MTs were prepared by solvothermal reaction in a highly basic condition. Typically, to obtain 0.38 M TTIP and 0.35 M TBAH precursor solution, 12 mmol TTIP (97 %, Aldrich) was dissolved in 20 mL ethanol, and then 11 mmol TBAH (40 wt% aqueous solution, Acros Organics) was added slowly. Resultant volume of the solution was 31.4 mL, and the amount of H2O included was 4.28 g. When the concentration of TBAH was varied, to maintain the same amount of H2O in the precursor solution, additional H2O was added or the H2O in the original reagent of TBAH was partially removed by using a vacuum evaporator. The resultant precursor solution was gently stirred for 30 min, and then transferred to a 0.1 L Teflon-lined titanium bomb. The reactor temperature was increased to 240 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, and the solvothermal reaction was then conducted for 8 h. The prepared white precipitate was collected and washed three times with ethanol to eliminate organic impurities. The structures of TiO2 products can be changed by the ratio of TTIP and TBAH. TiO2 HMSs were formed at the relatively lower concentrations of TTIP and TBAH, as the precise preparation condition is described in the previous work [48]. Typically, to prepare 0.19 M TTIP and 0.12 M TBAH precursor solution, 6 mmol TTIP and 4 mmol TBAH were dissolved in the solvent, composed of 22.8 mL ethanol and 2.7 mL H2O. The rest of the reaction conditions was the same as those applied for the preparation of TiO2 MT samples. As the control experiment, tetramethyl ammonium hydroxide (TMAH) or tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAH) was employed instead of TBAH. That is, 12 mmol TTIP was added to 20 mL ethanol, and 11 mmol TMAH (25 wt% aqueous solution, Sigma-Aldrich) or 11 mmol TPAH (1.0 M aqueous solution, Sigma-Aldrich) was slowly added to this solution. Other reaction conditions were the same as those applied for the preparation of TiO2 MT samples. Nitrogen-doped TiO2 (N-TiO2) MTs and N-TiO2 NPs were prepared by the procedure described below [49,50]. Two grams of the as-prepared TiO2 MTs or TiO2 NPs (Aeroxide P25, or P25) with average particles size of ∼21 nm was placed in an Al2O3 boat, located in a tube furnace (Lind-berg Inc., Model No. STF55356C). At the temperature of 550 ◦C, a pure ammonia gas (Matheson Inc., 99 %) was then flown with a rate of 0.7 L/min for 4 h [49,50]. 2.2 Photocatalytic activity measurements under UV–visible light First, photocatalytic activities of TiO2 MT and NP were determined by analyzing the decomposition of gaseous IPA. 8 mg of photocatalytic powders was placed on a Pyrex glass (2.5 cm × 2.5 cm). The whole area of photocatalytic sample was illuminated by a 300 W Xe lamp (Oriol) through a water filter to cut-off IR-region photons. After evacuation of a gas-tight reactor described in the previous report [49,51], 1.6 μL IPA diluted in water (IPA: H2O = 1: 1 in volume) was injected to the reactor, inducing the initial concentration of IPA to be 590 ppm in volume (ppmv). The pressure of the reactor was then adjusted to 760 Torr by filling the air. The concentrations of IPA and CO2 evolved were detected by a gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, Model 6890 N) installed with FID detector and methanizer. Second, the photocatalytic activity was also determined by measuring the removal of SA in aqueous solution. 10 mg of each photocatalytic sample was dispersed in 50 mL of a 150 μM SA aqueous solution. SA concentrations were then estimated by analyzing the absorbance at 296 nm using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Perkin−Elmer, Model Lambda 40). 2.3 Photocatalytic activity measurements under visible light A 300 W Xe lamp, installed with a UV cut-off filter (≤422 nm, ZUL0422 ASAHI Co.) and a water filter, was used as visible light source. To evaluate decomposition of gaseous IPA, 1.6 μL liquid IPA diluted in water (IPA: H2O = 1: 9 in volume) was inserted to the reactor, leading the initial concentration of IPA to be 117 ppmv. Other conditions were the same as those employed to the photocatalytic measurements in UV–visible light. In monitoring decomposition of aqueous SA under visible light, the initial concentration of SA was 25 μM. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selective synthesis of TiO2 MT structures To determine optimal condition for the selective formation of TiO2 MT structures, firstly, we varied the concentration of TBAH from 0.01 M to 0.45 M at the fixed concentration of 0.19 M TTIP which is a typical concentration used for the synthesis of TiO2 NPs by hydrothermal or solvothermal reactions [48]. By the solvothermal reaction at 240 °C for 8 h, TiO2 NPs with an average size of 15 nm were prepared at 0.01 M concentration of the TBAH, and more crystallized NPs with a size of ∼30 nm were obtained at 0.03 M TBAH, as shown in Fig. S1. The TiO2 HMSs with diameters of 1–3 µm were formed at the range of 0.12–0.25 M TBAH (Fig. S2a-c). Interestingly, further increase of TBAH concentration to 0.32–0.38 M resulted in formation of TiO2 MT structures mixed with TiO2 HMS and random-shaped TiO2 (Fig. S2d and e). Then, most of them disappeared when the TBAH concentration was increased to 0.45 M (Fig. S2f). Secondly, the same solvothermal reactions were attempted at a relatively higher TTIP concentration of 0.38 M, while the concentrations of TBAH were varied from 0.12 M to 0.45 M. As seen in Fig. 1, shapes of TiO2 structures are strongly dependent on the concentration of TBAH. At 0.12 M TBAH, the TiO2 HMS structures with diameters of 2–4 µm were formed, whereas further increase of TBAH concentration led to the deformation of hollow spherical structures and gradual formation of TiO2 MT structures. Particularly, the characteristic TiO2 MT structures with high morphological purity were obtained at the concentration of 0.32 M and 0.38 M of the TBAH, whereas the TBAH concentration above 0.38 M, for example 0.45 M, led to collapse of TiO2 MT structures. Thus, the concentrations of TTIP and TBAH in the solvothermal reaction are critical in determining the morphological phase of TiO2. Thirdly, to analyze the effect of the concentrations of the Ti-precursor, we varied the TTIP concentrations to the range of 0.19–0.51 M while the concentration of TBAH was kept at 0.38 M. At the comparatively low concentrations of TTIP, i.e., 0.19 M and 0.25 M, a slight amount of TiO2 MT phase were included among the random-shaped TiO2 aggregates ( Fig. 2). The appropriate concentrations of TTIP for the formation of TiO2 MTs turned out to be 0.32–0.45 M, whereas 0.51 M TTIP leads to a partial collapse of TiO2 MT structures with inclusion of considerable impurity phases. Based on our experimental results, the phase diagram for the distribution of TiO2 nanostructures was constructed with respective concentrations of the TTIP and TBAH, as shown in Fig. 3. HMS phase was formed at the comparatively lower concentration ranges of TTIP and TBAH. Contrarily, the MT phase was obtained rather at higher concentrations of TTIP and TBAH, but it was formed only in a narrow range of the concentrations. The MT structures with high purity were formed at the TTIP/TBAH concentrations of 0.32–0.45 M/0.32–0.38 M, as indicated in the dotted area of Fig. 3. After fine-tuning the experimental conditions, optimum composition of the reactants for the selective formation of the MT phase was determined to be 0.38 M TTIP and 0.35 M TBAH. The TiO2 structures prepared at this condition exhibit highly uniform MT structures with negligible impurity phases, as seen in Fig. 4. The average outer diameter of the TiO2 MTs was determined to be ∼2 µm without noticeable deviation in their diameters, but their lengths were deviated in the range of 15–30 µm. High magnification SEM image (Fig. 4e) shows that the wall of TiO2 MT is composed of tightly aggregated TiO2 NPs and its average thickness is about 200 nm, indicating the channel diameter of TiO2 MT to be ∼1.6 µm. 3.2 Characterizations of TiO2 MT structures Fig. 5a shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for the TiO2 HMSs prepared at the 0.19 M TTIP/0.12 M TBAH and the TiO2 MTs prepared at the 0.38 M TTIP/0.35 M TBAH, indicating that they are composed of the pure anatase phase. The crystallite size of TiO2 in the MT structure, evaluated from the (101) diffraction peak by applying Scherrer equation, was 28 nm, which is considerably bigger than the size of TiO2 HMS (12 nm). The observed result suggests that the growth of the TiO2 grains consisting of the MT structures is expedited under high concentrations of the TTIP and TBAH. BET surface areas of TiO2 HMSs and MTs were 43.1 and 35.2 m2g−1, respectively (Table S1). As shown in the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 5b, several local peaks are found for the TiO2 HMSs and MTs samples. For the HMS powders, the peak position in the lowest size region was ∼12 nm, which is regarded as average size of the pores formed in the shell of HMS composed of TiO2 NPs. Larger pores (>50 nm) are regarded to originate from the interstitial sites formed by packing of the HMSs. With the same method, average pore size of ∼18 nm was determined for the TiO2 MTs. The significantly larger pores of the MT phase are attributed to the primary TiO2 NPs of much larger size, which was induced by the fast grain growth in a high precursor concentration and a highly basic environment. To examine the thermal stability, the as-prepared TiO2 MTs were post-annealed at 600 °C for 1 h in air. As shown in Fig. 4f, the structure of the thermally-treated TiO2 MTs is not significantly changed from that of the as-prepared MTs (Fig. 4d), clearly indicating that the prepared TiO2 MTs are a highly robust structure. 3.3 Formation mechanism of TiO2 MT structures To analyze the formation mechanism of TiO2 MT structures, we analyzed the intermediates formed during the solvothermal reaction. After elapse of 0–20 min from the moment when the reaction temperature reached 240 °C, the reaction was quenched by a sudden cooling of the autoclave. The collected reaction intermediates were then analyzed by TEM and SEM techniques. When the reactant solution just reached 240 °C, a pale yellowish transparent solution was formed ( Fig. 6a). TEM image in Fig. 6b indicates that nanofiber-like structures with a size of ∼15 nm were formed in this reactant solution. After elapse of 5 min, the morphology of the initial nanofiber-like structure remained unchanged (Fig. 6c). However, after 10 min, the initially prepared nanofiber-like structures were completely diminished, and nanoparticular structures with a size of about 10 nm were evolved and aggregated with each other (Fig. 6d), whereas the reactant solution remained transparent. After 15 min, the clear solution was changed to turbid (see Fig. 6a), and TEM image for the collected precipitates exhibits that the primary particles are partially crystallized to form nearly 40 nm-sized particular structures and are heavily aggregated to form very large lump, as shown in Fig. 6e. However, the information about shape and morphology of the large lump cannot be acquired from the TEM image. The intermediates formed at the early solvothermal reactions were also examined by SEM technique. Fig. 6f-h show the intermediates formed by the reactions at 240 °C for 15 min, 17.5 min, and 20 min. After 15 min, a cylindrical titania structure with a diameter of ∼1.3 µm and a length of ∼2 µm was made (Fig. 6f). In 17.5 min, the length of the column was increased up to ∼3 µm, and a hole was formed at the center of circular plane in the cylindrical structure while the diameter of the cylinder was slightly increased (Fig. 6g). Further, after elapse of 20 min, the hole in the center of circular plane was enlarged to 400 nm and the average length of cylinder was increased to ∼5 µm with further increasing its outer diameter (Fig. 6h). The outer diameters of the intermediate prepared in 20 min were not significantly different from those of the TiO2 MTs prepared in 8 h of solvothermal reaction, although their pore size and the wall thickness were significantly smaller and larger, respectively. This result suggests that the overall shape of the tubular structure is determined at the early stage of the solvothermal reaction. Previously, J. H. Pan and other research groups investigated the formation mechanisms of the hydrous TiO2 colloidal spheres (HTCSs) during the controlled hydrolysis reaction of titanium alkoxide at ambient condition [52–55]. Due to the structure-directing agents (SDAs) such as amines [54,55], the hydrous TiO2 nuclei with a few nanometer-size were initially formed by the hydrolysis of TTIP, and subsequently assembled to form large HTCSs. The driving force for the aggregation of these nuclei is considered as an attractive interaction to decrease their surface energy. As the size of HTCSs increases, their total charges will increase gradually, because individual nuclei take on a small charge caused by the added SDA. Eventually, HTCSs will lose driving force for the further aggregation of nuclei, thus leading them not to grow beyond a certain size. These attractive and repulsive interactions caused the formation of the highly uniform HTCSs with diameters in the range of 50 nm – a few μm without mutual aggregation [53,56,57]. The reaction condition for the preparation of TiO2 MTs is quite different from that of HTCSs, because the aggregation and crystallization process occur in a solvothermal condition at elevated temperatures, but the basic concept for the formation of aggregated structures can be the same. Initially formed nanofiber-like structures are surmised to be the Ti-TBAH complexes generated by the reactions between TTIP, H2O and TBAH. As the sol-gel reaction at the elevated temperature progresses, the nanofiber-like complex is decomposed to form the nanoparticle-like nuclei, which are amorphous hydrous titania with a size of about 10 nm. These nanoparticle-like nuclei are gradually crystallized and aggregated to form the large cylindrical structures to minimize the surface energy. In our experiments, the hollow spherical structures were formed at relatively lower concentrations of the TBAH and TTIP, whereas the cylindrical structures were obtained at higher concentrations, suggesting that the structure of the self-assembled aggregates is strongly influenced by the concentrations of TBAH and TTIP. However, the specific reason to form a cylindrical structure at their high concentrations has to be further investigated. With further progress of solvothermal reaction, a small hole was formed in the center of the circular plane of the cylindrical structure. We believe it is attributed to the release of 1-butene gas bubbles, as reported previously [48]. That is, the TBAH contained in the cylindrical aggregates are decomposed to evolve 1-butene gas under an elevated temperature during the solvothermal reaction, as shown in the following reaction. (C4H9)4NOH (l) → (C4H9)3N (l) + C4H8 (g) + H2O (l). As a result, a small hole could be created by an abrupt ejection of 1-butene gas from the cylindrical aggregates. With elapse of a long reaction time, the dissolution and crystallization by Ostwald refinement occur continuously, leading to gradual enlargement of the pore diameter and the crystallinity of wall structures, as the overall preparation pathway is described in Fig. 6a. To confirm the unique role of TBAH, we examined other alkyl ammonium hydroxides. That is, 0.35 M TMAH and TPAH were used, while the concentration of TTIP was kept at 0.38 M during the solvothermal reaction. After the solvothermal reaction at 240 °C for 8 h, the obtained TiO2 structures by employing TMAH were very large TiO2 particles of 100–200 nm sizes with inclusion of randomly aggregated structures (see Fig. S3a), and those with TPAH were relatively smaller particles in the range of 50–100 nm (Fig. S3b). Noticeably, no tubular structures were formed in both reactions, suggesting that formation of TiO2 MTs was caused by the unique role of TBAH. It is concluded that TBAH with bulky alkyl group is a favorable SDA for the formation of large cylindrical aggregate structures, and the 1-butene gas bubbles produced by thermal decomposition of tertiary butoxide group plays a key role in creating the hole in the cylindrical structure. 3.4 Photocatalytic property of TiO2 MT-based structures We analyzed photocatalytic properties of bareTiO2 MTs and N-TiO2 MTs in decomposing gaseous IPA and aqueous SA under UV–visible light and visible light, respectively. First, the photocatalytic activities of TiO2 MT were evaluated under UV–visible light using 300 W Xe lamp as a light source, and a commercial TiO2 NP (Aeroxide P25) was used as a control. 590 ppmv IPA vapor was completely decomposed in 3 h ( Fig. 7a). The quantity of CO2 released was proportional to the irradiation time. In 3 h, the evolved CO2 was 584 ppmv, but it was 7 % lower than that of TiO2 NP (Fig. 7b). The photocatalytic efficiencies of TiO2 MT and TiO2 NPs were also evaluated by monitoring aqueous SA degradation. The photocatalytic removal reaction of SA could be described by first order kinetics with the equation of –d[c]/dt = k r [c], where [c] is the concentration of SA, and t and k r denote the reaction time (min) and the degradation rate constant (μM h−1), respectively. As seen in Fig. 7c, k r value of TiO2 MT was measured to be 88 % comparing with that of TiO2 NP. TiO2 MT has clear advantages in space-charge separation of electron/hole pairs and mass transport of chemical species but has slightly lower photocatalytic activity than TiO2 NP. The P25 prepared by flame hydrolysis is a multiphasic TiO2 NPs composed of anatase and rutile phases [58,59]. Its main phase is anatase, and the composition of the rutile phase is in the range of 15–30 %. The P25 used in this study contains 16 % rutile phase and has a BET surface area and average particle size of 62.7 m2g−1 and ∼21 nm, respectively. The microstructure of P25 has been investigated by various research groups. The proposed structures of P25 are a simple mixture of anatase and rutile NPs [60], a homojunction structure consisting of anatase NPs and rutile clusters or thin layers [59,61], and an inter-granular junction structure of anatase and rutile NPs [62]. Although its exact microstructure has not yet been elucidated, multiphasic P25 is expected to be an effective structure for space-charge separation and suppression of charge recombination [58,63,64]. The bandgaps of anatase and rutile crystals are 3.20 eV and 3.03 eV, respectively, and the CB level of anatase phase is 0.2 V higher than that of the rutile [65]. Thus, upon band gap excitation, the photo-excited electrons from the anatase moiety can migrate to the CB of the rutile. Therefore, both TiO2 structures are highly efficient in blocking charge separation, and it is inferred that slightly lower activity of TiO2 MT is mainly due to its lower surface area (35.2 m2g−1) comparing to that of TiO2 NP (62.7 m2g−1). Second, to evaluate photocatalytic property under visible light, nitrogen-doped TiO2 (N-TiO2) MTs were prepared by flowing NH3 gas to the as-prepared TiO2 MTs at 550 °C [49,50]. As a control, N-TiO2 NPs were also prepared by applying the same nitrogen-doping process to the P25. The structure of TiO2 MT was not changed by the nitrogen doping process at 550 °C, as shown in SEM image of Fig. S4, whereas its surface area was slightly decreased, as listed in Table S1. UV–visible absorption spectra in Fig. S5 reveal that the absorption edge of N-TiO2 MTs was significantly red-shifted, thus allowing the utilization of visible light up to ∼490 nm. The prepared N-TiO2 MTs and NPs were then employed for the photocatalytic decomposition of gaseous IPA in a visible light illumination (λ ≥ 422 nm). The initial concentration of gaseous IPA, filled in the gas-tight reactor, was 117 ppmv. Hence, the complete decomposition of IPA can lead to an evolution of 351 ppmv CO2. By employing the N-TiO2 MTs with illuminating the visible light, IPA vapor was completely removed in 4 h, whereas it took about 10 h for the N-TiO2 NPs ( Fig. 8a). Moreover, as shown in Fig. 8b, the amount of CO2 evolved in 4 h was 42.3 ppmv, which is 2.2 times of CO2 evolved from the N-TiO2 NPs, although their surface area is only 58 % that of N-TiO2 NPs (Table S1). Fig. 8c shows the IPA decomposition and CO2 evolution with N-TiO2 MTs for a long-period of visible light irradiation. In 4 h, the IPA was completely removed, and the level of acetone, considered to be a major intermediate, was maximized. The acetone was then disappeared completely in about 25 h, and finally, in about 30 h, the quantity of CO2 evolved reached the maximum level (343 ppm), which was very close to the theoretical value (351 ppm). Therefore, IPA can be completely mineralized by N-TiO2 MTs under a visible light condition. Decomposition of SA in aqueous solution was also monitored under a visible light illumination (λ ≥ 422 nm). Noticeably, k r of N-TiO2 MT was 3.4 times that of N-TiO2 NP (Fig. 8d). Then, why does N-TiO2 MT exhibits much higher visible light photocatalytic efficiency, comparing with N-TiO2 NP, although TiO2 MT show comparatively lower efficiency under UV–visible light. Doping of nitrogen into the TiO2 induces formation of new energy levels that originated from N 2p atomic orbital on the top of the TiO2 valence band (VB) [66,67]. As a result, its bandgap becomes narrower, thus extending light absorption up to the visible light region. In contrast, the new energy levels created on the top of the VB can act as a recombination center for the photogenerated electron/hole pairs. Thus, in nitrogen-doped TiO2 systems, the issue of charge recombination becomes critical in determining photocatalytic activities. That is, to obtain high activity, suppression of charge recombination becomes much more important for the nitrogen-doped TiO2 systems. It was reported that large and aggregated TiO2 structures can provide higher photocatalytic activity comparing with nano-sized TiO2 particles, due to more effective space-charge separation [68,69]. With this respect, micro-tubular structure of N-TiO2 MT has clear advantages in suppressing charge recombination, as its highly crystallized wall structure consisting of tightly interconnected TiO2 NPs is suitable for efficient space-charge separation. In addition, the spacious and straight pore channel will allow efficient transport of reactants and products. As demonstrated, TiO2 MTs possess essential properties that are required for high-efficiency photocatalysts. They could be used as a core framework for designing diverse photocatalytic systems operating under UV and/or visible light conditions. Particularly, N-TiO2 MTs are expected to be a key component of visible light photocatalysts in decomposing organic pollutants, producing hydrogen from water splitting, converting CO2 into solar fuels, and others. More attention and further investigations are necessary to this novel TiO2 MT-based structures. 4 Conclusions The combined concentrations of the TTIP and TBAH during the solvothermal reaction at 240 °C were critical for the selective synthesis of TiO2 MT structures. The TiO2 MTs were formed in a specific composition range at 0.32–0.45 M TTIP/0.32–0.38 M TBAH, and the optimum condition turned out to be 0.38 M/0.35 M. The prepared TiO2 MTs with an average pore diameter of ∼1.6 µm, a wall thickness of ∼200 nm and lengths of 15–30 µm are physically robust and thermally stable. The crystallite size of TiO2 in the MT structure is 28 nm, considerably larger size than that of TiO2 in the HMS structure. To investigate the formation mechanism step-by-step, an insight analysis into the initial stage of the solvothermal reaction was conducted. The nanoparticle-like nuclei with a size of ∼10 nm are formed by decomposition of the initially formed nanofiber-like structure, and then aggregated to form the cylindrical structures. Afterward, a small hole is formed in the center of the circular plane of the cylindrical structure by an abrupt ejection of the 1-butene gas that originates from TBAH. Then the pore is gradually enlarged, and the wall structure becomes highly crystallized by the Ostwald refinement. In decomposing IPA vapor and aqueous SA under UV–visible light, TiO2 MT shows slightly lower activity than TiO2 NP. This is mainly due to its lower surface area (35.2 m2g−1) than that of TiO2 NP (62.7 m2g−1). In contrast, under visible light irradiation, N-TiO2 MTs exhibits 2.2 times of catalytic activity in producing CO2 from gaseous IPA and 3.4 times of k r in removing aqueous SA than N-TiO2 NPs. In N-doped TiO2 systems, the charge recombination issue is critical in determining photocatalytic activities, because the new energy levels formed on the top of TiO2 VB can act as a major charge recombination pathway. Therefore, notably high photocatalytic performance of N-TiO2 MTs is mainly caused by the highly crystallized integrated structure providing efficient space-charge separation. coredata.dc:description: Novel TiO2 microtubes (MTs) with a pore size of ∼1.6 µm, a wall thickness of ∼200 nm, and lengths of 15–30 µm were synthesized by solvothermal reaction without templates. TiO2 MTs, self-assembled with highly crystallized anatase particles, were obtained at the specific concentration ranges of titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP) and tetrabutyl ammonium hydroxide (TBAH) (0.32–0.45 M TTIP and 0.32–0.38 M TBAH). We also prepared nitrogen-doped TiO2 (N-TiO2) MTs by flowing gaseous ammonia to the bare TiO2 MTs at 550 °C and analyzed the photocatalytic properties of TiO2 MT and N-TiO2 MT in decomposing gaseous isopropanol (IPA) and aqueous salicylic acid (SA). Under UV–visible light illumination TiO2 MT showed slightly lower photocatalytic activities than commercial TiO2 NP (Aeroxide P25), but under visible light N-TiO2 MT demonstrated 2.2–3.4 times higher activities than N-TiO2 NP, presumably due to its effective structure for space-charge separation of the photogenerated electron/hole pairs.
coredata.dc:title: Template-free synthesis of novel TiO2 microtube (MT) and N-doped MT and their photocatalytic properties decomposing organic compounds
